prop.head.label.name: Chapter
prop.head.headtext: Appeal from a Judgment or Order of a District Court

head.headtext: Motion to certify order in multiple claim case [Fed. R. Civ. P. 54(b)]

form.para.form.text: Plaintiff [name of plaintiff] moves pursuant to F.R.C.P. Rule 54(b) for this court to amend its Order Granting Partial Summary Judgment dated [date of judgment] to include therein an additional paragraph stating: “This Court determines that there is no just reason for delay and it directs the Clerk to enter judgment based on this order.”
The purpose of this motion, as more fully explained in the brief filed herewith, is to allow an appeal from the foregoing order while other unrelated claims remain in this cause.

para.paratext:
When an action raises more than one claim, the district court may direct entry of judgment on one or more, but less than all of the claims. No appeal is permitted from such judgment until all claims have been disposed of, unless the district court makes an express determination that there is no just reason for delay and it expressly directs entry of final judgment on the determined claims. The district court's determination that there is no just reason for delay and its direction for entry of judgment, both of which are required under Fed. R. Civ. P. 54(b), are collectively called certification. The district court's failure to recite the lack of any just reason for delay will not defeat appellate jurisdiction where the district court's intent to enter a final judgment is unmistakable.
Kelly v. Lee's Old Fashioned Hamburgers, Inc. (Lee's Old Fashioned Hamburgers of New Orleans, Inc.), 908 F.2d 1218, 17 Fed. R. Serv. 3d 369 (5th Cir. 1990); AFGE Local 1533 v. Cheney, 944 F.2d 503, n.1 (9th Cir. 1991). Where that intent is unclear, the court of appeals will not treat the judgment as final.
Willhauck v. Halpin, 953 F.2d 689, 702 (1st Cir. 1991). This rule does not create finality; it simply creates a procedure for appealing from a final order before the court decides other claims in the same case.
Zucker v. Maxicare Health Plans Inc., 14 F.3d 477, 483 (9th Cir. 1994) (judgment subject to conditions was not made final by certification); InverWorld, Ltd. v. C.I.R., 979 F.2d 868, 874, (D.C. Cir. 1992). A court may be more relaxed about shortcomings in the district court's certification when this would allow it to consider a pending appeal, in contrast to the reverse situation where appellee argues that an earlier certification was adequate and thus the current appeal is too late.
Boston Property Exchange Transfer Co. v. Iantosca, 720 F.3d 1, 8, 85 Fed. R. Serv. 3d 934 (1st Cir. 2013); Akers v. Alvey, 338 F.3d 491, 495, 2003 FED App. 0256P (6th Cir. 2003); St. Paul Fire and Marine Ins. Co. v. PepsiCo, Inc., 884 F.2d 688, 693, 14 Fed. R. Serv. 3d 1165 (2d Cir. 1989).

Either party may ask the district court to certify a ruling. The losing party may seek certification so that it can appeal without waiting for final judgment on all claims. The prevailing party may want certification as a way of forcing the loser to decide whether to appeal, since appeal must be taken with the appeal period that starts with entry of a properly certified ruling. In other words, once a ruling is properly certified under Fed. R. Civ. P. 54(b), a would-be appellant does not have the option of waiting until final judgment on other claims before appealing the certified ruling.
Construction Industry Retirement Fund of Rockford, Ill. v. Kasper Trucking, Inc., 10 F.3d 465, 467–68, 27 Fed. R. Serv. 3d 478 (7th Cir. 1993) (appeal period runs from entry of order, so appellant cannot elect to wait to appeal after judgment on remaining claims). The appeal period starts with entry of the order or judgment in accordance with Rule 54(b) and the separate document requirements of Rule 58 (Cooper v. Town of East Hampton, 83 F.3d 31, 34–35, 34 Fed. R. Serv. 3d 979 (2d Cir. 1996)), not with the later entry of the district court's findings or order explaining its certification.
In re Lindsay, 59 F.3d 942 (9th Cir. 1995).

Several circuits have taken the restrictive view that Fed. R. Civ. P. 54(b) only applies when the district court resolves all claims concerning a single party, or all parties concerning a single claim.
Steve's Homemade Ice Cream, Inc. v. Stewart, 907 F.2d 364, 17 Fed. R. Serv. 3d 29 (2d Cir. 1990); Horn v. Transcon Lines, Inc., 898 F.2d 589, 16 Fed. R. Serv. 3d 980 (7th Cir. 1990).

Advanced Magnetics, Inc. v. Bayfront Partners, Inc., 106 F.3d 11, 16, 36 Fed. R. Serv. 3d 1458 (2d Cir. 1997) (requirement satisfied when all claims dismissed against a party in one capacity, even though it remained a party in another capacity).

The First Circuit's position is not per se, but it claims it has yet to encounter an appeal justifying an exception to this principle. See Nichols v. Cadle Co., 101 F.3d 1448, 36 Fed. R. Serv. 3d 1067 (1st Cir. 1996). Even if there is no per se rule against appeal by one party on one claim, courts still may hesitate to allow immediate appeal when a later appeal by another party might require revisiting the same issue.
Cooper Power Systems, Inc. v. Union Carbide Chemicals & Plastics Co., Inc., 123 F.3d 675, n.1, 33 U.C.C. Rep. Serv. 2d 803 (7th Cir. 1997).

Circuit courts require the district court to articulate the reasons for certification, so that they can determine if the district court abused its discretion in certifying its ruling.
Knafel v. Pepsi Cola Bottlers of Akron, Inc., 850 F.2d 1155 (6th Cir. 1988); Frank Briscoe Co., Inc. v. Morrison-Knudsen Co., Inc., 776 F.2d 1414, 3 Fed. R. Serv. 3d 693 (9th Cir. 1985); Ansam Associates, Inc. v. Cola Petroleum, Ltd., 760 F.2d 442, 1 Fed. R. Serv. 3d 1071 (2d Cir. 1985). See also Explosives Supply Co., Inc. v. Columbia Nitrogen Corp., 691 F.2d 486, 35 Fed. R. Serv. 2d 402 (11th Cir. 1982) (accepting appeal based on district court's separate opinion).
The kind of district court statement that will bolster certification is illustrated by National Fuel Gas Distribution Corp. v. TGX Corp., 950 F.2d 829, 834 (2d Cir. 1991).

New Mexico v. Trujillo, 813 F.3d 1308, 1316–17 (10th Cir. 2016) (certification that only recites language of Rule 54(b) with no explanation of how it applies is inadequate); iLOR, LLC v. Google, Inc., 550 F.3d 1067, 1072 (Fed. Cir. 2008) (recital of “no just reason for delay” without explanation was inadequate certification); McAdams v. McCord, 533 F.3d 924, 71 Fed. R. Serv. 3d 71 (8th Cir. 2008) (appeal dismissed where district court failed to explain why there was no just reason for delay); Union County, Iowa v. Piper Jaffray & Co., Inc., 525 F.3d 643, 647 (8th Cir. 2008) (district court findings needed to show how certificate will advance ultimate termination). If a district court fails to give supporting reasons, the court of appeals may evaluate the case and make an independent determination of whether certification was justified.
Pension Ben. Guar. Corp. v. LTV Corp., 875 F.2d 1008, 1013, 16 Fed. R. Serv. 3d 400 (2d Cir. 1989), judgment rev'd on other grounds, 496 U.S. 633, 110 S. Ct. 2668, 110 L. Ed. 2d 579 (1990), relying on Curtiss-Wright Corp. v. General Elec. Co., 446 U.S. 1, 100 S. Ct. 1460, 64 L. Ed. 2d 1, 29 Fed. R. Serv. 2d 221 (1980).

The Fourth Circuit has warned that it may remand future appeals for clarification if the district court's reasons are unclear.
Braswell Shipyards, Inc. v. Beazer East, Inc., 2 F.3d 1331, 1336, 26 Fed. R. Serv. 3d 807 (4th Cir. 1993).

But see Fox v. Baltimore City Police Dept., 201 F.3d 526, 531–32, 45 Fed. R. Serv. 3d 828 (4th Cir. 2000) (if record reveals sound basis for certification, court of appeals will allow appeal without district court explanation). The more the district court explains the reasons for its certification, the more likely the court of appeals may be to defer to the district court's decision.
Cadillac Fairview/California, Inc. v. U.S., 41 F.3d 562, n.1 (9th Cir. 1994).
Bingham v. City of Manhattan Beach, 341 F.3d 939, n.1 (9th Cir. 2003).

If an appeal is erroneously taken without a certification, the court of appeals will dismiss it and indicate that it will retain the record for a second appeal if the district court certifies its ruling under Fed. R. Civ. P. 54(b).
Oak Const. Co. v. Huron Cement Co., 475 F.2d 1220 (6th Cir. 1973).

The court of appeals also may order a limited remand and ask the district court to cure any problem with its certification.
National Ass'n of Home Builders v. Norton, 340 F.3d 835, 840 (9th Cir. 2003). Alternatively, the court of appeals may remand for the limited purpose of allowing the district court to consider whether to make such a certification.
Clear Channel Outdoor, Inc. v. City of St. Paul, 618 F.3d 851, 855 (8th Cir. 2010). Do not assume, however, that the district court will automatically certify its ruling after an abortive appeal without certification.
Kirtland v. J. Ray McDermott & Co., 568 F.2d 1166 (5th Cir. 1978). If the district court certifies its ruling, file a new notice of appeal. A stipulation to transfer the record from the aborted appeal to the new appeal has been leniently treated as a notice of appeal.
Noa v. Key Futures, Inc., 638 F.2d 77, 29 Fed. R. Serv. 2d 1560 (9th Cir. 1980). Most circuits have concluded that a certification secured after the notice of appeal operates nunc pro tunc to the date when the appeal was filed.
Good v. Ohio Edison Co., 104 F.3d 93, 36 Fed. R. Serv. 3d 409, 1997 FED App. 0004P (6th Cir. 1997) (premature appeal ripens upon 54(b) certification); Kelley v. Michaels, 59 F.3d 1055, 1057, 32 Fed. R. Serv. 3d 469 (10th Cir. 1995); Instructional Systems, Inc. v. Computer Curriculum Corp., 35 F.3d 813, n.9 (3d Cir. 1994); Martinez v. Arrow Truck Sales, Inc., 865 F.2d 160 (8th Cir. 1988); Lewis v. B.F. Goodrich Co., 850 F.2d 641, 11 Fed. R. Serv. 3d 967 (10th Cir. 1988); Tidler v. Eli Lilly and Co., Inc., 824 F.2d 84, 8 Fed. R. Serv. 3d 707 (D.C. Cir. 1987); Metallurgical Industries, Inc. v. Fourtek, Inc., 771 F.2d 915, 3 Fed. R. Serv. 3d 835 (5th Cir. 1985); Lac Courte Oreilles Band of Lake Superior Chippewa Indians v. State of Wis., 760 F.2d 177, 2 Fed. R. Serv. 3d 362 (7th Cir. 1985); Freeman v. Hittle, 747 F.2d 1299, 40 Fed. R. Serv. 2d 746 (9th Cir. 1984); Tilden Financial Corp. v. Palo Tire Service, Inc., 596 F.2d 604, 607, 27 Fed. R. Serv. 2d 442 (3d Cir. 1979).

The Supreme Court's restrictions in FirsTier Mortg. Co. v. Investors Mortg. Ins. Co., 498 U.S. 269, 111 S. Ct. 648, 112 L. Ed. 2d 743, 18 Fed. R. Serv. 3d 385 (1991) on some other premature appeals does not change this result.
Clausen v. Sea-3, Inc., 21 F.3d 1181, 40 Fed. R. Evid. Serv. 881, 28 Fed. R. Serv. 3d 1400 (1st Cir. 1994).

Cousin v. Small, 325 F.3d 627 (5th Cir. 2003); U.S. v. Brown, 348 F.3d 1200, 1206 (10th Cir. 2003); Storage Technology Corp. v. Cisco Systems, Inc., 329 F.3d 823, 829–30 (Fed. Cir. 2003). Any right to cross appeal is limited to issues arising out of the same facts as the certified order.
Searcy v. City of Dayton, 38 F.3d 282, 289, 30 Fed. R. Serv. 3d 997, 1994 FED App. 0361P (6th Cir. 1994) (cross motions for summary judgment).

The Supreme Court has eliminated much uncertainty and confusion about the finality of decisions in consolidated cases. A district court ruling that finally decides one of several cases that have been consolidated is appealable without a Rule 54(b) certification. It does not matter if the consolidation was due to multidistrict litigation, Gelboim v. Bank of America Corp., 574 U.S. 405, 135 S. Ct. 897, 906, 190 L. Ed. 2d 789, 90 Fed. R. Serv. 3d 1060 (2015), or was ordered under Fed. R. Civ. P. 42(a).
Hall v. Hall, 138 S.Ct. 1118, 200 L.Ed.2d 399 (2018). Most importantly, it does not matter if the consolidation was for limited or all purposes. When one of the consolidated cases is finally decided and the losing party appeals, parties in the other cases consolidated with it may join in that appeal if the district court has decided the same issue in their cases and certified it under Rule 54(b).
Gelboim v. Bank of America Corp., 574 U.S. 405, 135 S. Ct. 897, 906, 190 L. Ed. 2d 789, 90 Fed. R. Serv. 3d 1060 (2015).

Unlike severance, separate trials for different parties does not remove those parties from a case. If their claims are resolved before the rest of the case, certification is required for any appeal because the case remains multiple party.
Brooks v. District Hosp. Partners, L.P., 606 F.3d 800, 805–06 (D.C. Cir. 2010).

Certification under Rule 54(b) has eliminated much of the uncertainty about when appeal can be taken from an order before final judgment on other claims. Appeal is still possible without certification from collateral orders, interlocutory orders appealable as a matter of right under 28 U.S.C.A. § 1292(a)(1), and orders denying intervention as a matter of right.
Purnell v. City of Akron, 925 F.2d 941, 19 Fed. R. Serv. 3d 577 (6th Cir. 1991).

One court has allowed appeal without certification where remaining claims could not logically survive a ruling.
American Nat. Bank and Trust Co. of Chicago v. Secretary of Housing and Urban Development of Washington, D.C., 946 F.2d 1286, 21 Fed. R. Serv. 3d 1265 (7th Cir. 1991). However, this seems to reintroduce the uncertainty Rule 54(b) was designed to end.

In Cuyahoga Valley Ry. Co. v. Tracy, 6 F.3d 389, 26 Fed. R. Serv. 3d 1186 (6th Cir. 1993), appeal was taken from earlier orders in a complex tax case even though the case proceeded in the trial court on other issues. The arguments on appeal assumed finality of the earlier orders, although no one mentioned the need for a Rule 54(b) certification to achieve that finality. The result is questionable.

Appeal from a properly certified order or judgment allows, as in other appeals from a final judgment, review of all orders leading to that certified order or judgment.
Meadaa v. K.A.P. Enterprises, L.L.C., 756 F.3d 875, 879, 88 Fed. R. Serv. 3d 1566 (5th Cir. 2014).

For a further discussion of this procedure, see Wright and Miller's Federal Practice and Procedure, Civil §§ 2653 to 3661, and Knibb, Federal Court of Appeals Manual §§ 3:1 et seq. (6th ed.). For other forms applicable to this procedure, see West's Federal Forms §§ 4589 to 4600 (3d ed.).
